title: Neurotoxicology
icd10: T43.8X5A (Adverse effect of other psychotropic drugs — lithium)
T45.1X5A (Adverse effect of antineoplastic/immunosuppressive drugs — checkpoint inhibitors)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of drug-induced neurotoxicity syndromes in adults. Covers three high-yield syndromes: (1) Lithium neurotoxicity, (2) Cefepime neurotoxicity/encephalopathy, and (3) Checkpoint inhibitor (immune checkpoint inhibitor) encephalitis. Includes recognition, diagnostic workup, acute treatment, and monitoring. Excludes chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (separate plan), neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and serotonin syndrome (addressed in other contexts).

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: Renal function (cefepime/lithium clearance), hepatic function, electrolytes
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Cr elevated = impaired clearance; electrolyte derangement

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: If lithium exposure; therapeutic 0.6-1.2 mEq/L; toxic >1.5; severe >2.5
Core Labs (Immediate).target: Therapeutic vs toxic range; correlate with symptoms

Core Labs (Immediate).rationale: If on cefepime; toxic typically >20 mcg/mL; renal adjustment needed
Rule out hepatic encephalopathy; can coexist with drug toxicity
Osmolar gap; hydration status; lithium toxicity correlation

Extended Labs.target: Identify neuronal antibody suggesting irAE encephalitis

Extended Labs.rationale: Inflammatory markers; checkpoint inhibitor irAE activity
Extended Labs.target: Elevated suggests active inflammation in irAE

Extended Labs.rationale: Checkpoint inhibitors can cause adrenal insufficiency (hypophysitis)
Extended Labs.target: Low cortisol = adrenal crisis; requires replacement

Extended Labs.rationale: Exclude co-intoxicants or other drug-induced encephalopathy
Exclude infection if febrile; immunosuppressed patients

Specialized Labs.item: CSF analysis — cell count, protein, glucose, cytology, autoimmune panel (89050, 89051, 84157, 82945, 83519)

Essential/First-line.target: Checkpoint inhibitor: limbic/cortical T2 hyperintensity; lithium: cerebellar/brainstem changes; cefepime: usually normal

Tumor staging in checkpoint inhibitor patients

Lithium Neurotoxicity — Specific Treatme.contraindications: Decompensated CHF, fluid overload, severe renal failure

dosing.instructions: Indications: level >4.0 mEq/L; severe symptoms (seizures, coma, cardiovascular instability); impaired renal function; level >2.5 mEq/L with symptoms; run until level <1.0 mEq/L; recheck 6-8h post-dialysis (rebound)

Lithium Neurotoxicity — Specific Treatme.monitoring: Lithium level q2h during and q6h post; electrolytes; rebound levels 6-8h post

Lithium Neurotoxicity — Specific Treatme.indication: Acute lithium ingestion within 1-2 hours, sustained-release preparations

dosing.instructions: 1-2 L/hr PO or via NG tube until rectal effluent clear; for acute ingestion of sustained-release lithium

Lithium Neurotoxicity — Specific Treatme.contraindications: Ileus, bowel obstruction, perforation, unprotected airway

dosing.instructions: Discontinue NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and diuretics (all increase lithium levels); hold until lithium cleared
Immediately discontinue cefepime; switch to alternative antibiotic class; resolution expected 24-72 hours

Referrals & Consults.item: Nephrology consult for lithium toxicity hemodialysis decisions and renal dosing guidance
Toxicology consult for lithium toxicity dosing guidance, hemodialysis timing, and co-intoxicant management
Infectious disease consult for cefepime neurotoxicity antibiotic alternatives and susceptibility-guided selection
Oncology consult for checkpoint inhibitor encephalitis treatment decisions and immunotherapy rechallenge guidance
Neurology consult for all etiologies: EEG interpretation, seizure management, NCSE detection, and SILENT syndrome evaluation
Critical care consult for ICU admission if GCS <12, refractory seizures, autonomic instability, or need for hemodialysis
Psychiatry consult for lithium neurotoxicity patients requiring mood stabilizer alternatives and psychiatric medication management
Pharmacy consult for renal dose adjustments (cefepime), drug interaction review (lithium), and alternative antibiotic selection

Patient/Family Instructions.item: **Lithium:** Educate on drug interactions (NSAIDs, ACEi, diuretics), hydration importance, and regular level monitoring
**Lithium:** Teach sick day rules — hold lithium during dehydration, vomiting, diarrhea, or febrile illness; seek medical attention
**Lithium:** Explain signs of toxicity (tremor, ataxia, confusion, slurred speech) requiring immediate medical evaluation
**Cefepime:** Reassure on reversibility — symptoms typically resolve 24-72 hours after drug discontinuation in most patients
**Cefepime:** Educate on importance of renal function monitoring and dose adjustment for any future cephalosporin use
**Checkpoint inhibitor:** Educate on irAE recognition — any new neurological symptoms (confusion, seizures, weakness) require emergency evaluation
**Checkpoint inhibitor:** Provide steroid taper education — emphasize completing the full taper and not stopping abruptly
**Checkpoint inhibitor:** Explain that neurological irAEs may occur weeks to months after starting immunotherapy

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: **Lithium:** Maintain adequate hydration (2-3 L/day); avoid dehydration from exercise, heat, or illness
**Lithium:** Regular lithium level monitoring (q3-6 months when stable; more frequently with dose changes or illness)
**Lithium:** Avoid NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and thiazide diuretics or use only with increased monitoring
**Cefepime:** Renal-dosed prescribing — always adjust cefepime dose for renal function before initiating
**Cefepime:** Trough level monitoring in patients with renal impairment (CrCl <60 mL/min) or age >65
**Checkpoint inhibitor:** Baseline neurological assessment before starting immunotherapy to detect new deficits early
**Checkpoint inhibitor:** Prompt reporting of any new neurological symptoms to oncology team throughout treatment course

differential.tests: MRI brain with contrast, oncology staging

monitoring.frequency: q6h acute; q12h stable; q3-6mo OPD
monitoring.action: If rising: increase fluids, consider hemodialysis
If declining: re-image, escalate treatment, neurology

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU for cefepime NCSE; daily routine otherwise
monitoring.action: If NCSE: AEDs; if worsening: escalate care
If declining: adjust drug dosing, nephrology consult
Correct derangements; Na affects lithium handling

monitoring.frequency: q1-2h if altered; q4h if stable
monitoring.action: If declining: re-image, EEG, escalate care, ICU if <12
If febrile: blood cultures, infection workup (especially immunosuppressed)
If arrhythmia or QTc prolongation: cardiology, electrolyte correction

disposition.criteria: GCS <12; refractory seizures or NCSE; need for hemodialysis (lithium); severe autonomic instability; need for intubation; Grade 3-4 checkpoint inhibitor encephalitis; lithium level >4.0 mEq/L
GCS 12-14 and improving; controlled seizures on AEDs; lithium level decreasing and <2.5 mEq/L; stable after hemodialysis; on continuous EEG monitoring
GCS 15; no seizures; lithium level <1.5 mEq/L and trending down; cefepime discontinued with symptoms improving; Grade 1-2 checkpoint inhibitor encephalitis on oral steroids

Neurologically at baseline; lithium level normalized; cefepime neurotoxicity fully resolved (24-72h); checkpoint inhibitor encephalitis: stable on oral steroid taper; follow-up arranged; caregiver education completed
